rdf:Description.NS0:background: Greece achieved its independence from the Ottoman Empire in 1829. During the second half of the 19th century and the first half of the 20th century, it gradually added neighboring islands and territories with Greek-speaking populations. Following the defeat of communist rebels in 1949, Greece joined NATO in 1952. A military dictatorship, which in 1967 suspended many political liberties and forced the king to flee the country, lasted seven years. Democratic elections in 1974 and a referendum created a parliamentary republic and abolished the monarchy; Greece joined the European Community or EC in 1981 (which became the EU in 1992).
rdf:Description.NS0:location: Southern Europe, bordering the Aegean Sea, Ionian Sea, and the Mediterranean Sea, between Albania and Turkey
rdf:Description.NS0:climate: temperate; mild, wet winters; hot, dry summers
rdf:Description.NS0:terrain: mostly mountains with ranges extending into the sea as peninsulas or chains of islands
rdf:Description.NS0:literacyDefinition: age 15 and over can read and write
rdf:Description.NS0:legalSystem: based on codified Roman law; judiciary divided into civil, criminal, and administrative courts
rdf:Description.NS0:suffrage: 18 years of age; universal and compulsory
rdf:Description.NS0:flagDescription: nine equal horizontal stripes of blue alternating with white; there is a blue square in the upper hoist-side corner bearing a white cross; the cross symbolizes Greek Orthodoxy, the established religion of the country
rdf:Description.NS0:economyOverview: Greece has a mixed capitalist economy with the public sector accounting for about half of GDP. Tourism is a key industry, providing a large portion of GDP and foreign exchange earnings. Greece is a major beneficiary of EU aid, equal to about 4%20 of GDP. The economy has improved steadily over the last few years, as the government has tightened policy in the run-up to Greece's entry into the EU's Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) on 1 January 2001. In particular, Greece has cut its budget deficit to below 1%20 of GDP and tightened monetary policy, with the result that inflation fell from 20%20 in 1990 to 3.1%20 in 2000. Major challenges remaining include the reduction of unemployment and further restructuring of the economy, including the privatization of some leading state enterprises. Growth, 3.8%20 in 2000, may fall off to 3%20-3.5%20 in 2001.
rdf:Description.NS0:telephoneSystemGeneralAssessment: adequate, modern networks reach all areas; good mobile telephone and international service
rdf:Description.NS0:telephoneSystemDomestic: microwave radio relay trunk system; extensive open wire connections; submarine cable to offshore islands
rdf:Description.NS0:telephoneSystemInternational: tropospheric scatter; 8 submarine cables; satellite earth stations - 2 Intelsat (1 Atlantic Ocean and 1 Indian Ocean), 1 Eutelsat, and 1 Inmarsat (Indian Ocean region)
rdf:Description.NS0:internationalDispute: complex maritime, air, and territorial disputes with Turkey in Aegean Sea
dispute with The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia over its name
rdf:Description.NS0:illicitDrugs: a gateway to Europe for traffickers smuggling cannabis and heroin from the Middle East and Southwest Asia to the West and precursor chemicals to the East
some South American cocaine transits or is consumed in Greece
